Generate an {emojiscape}

emoji
emojiscape
r
Author

Matt Dray

Published

June 26, 2021

tl;dr

You can print a little emoji scene to your R console with the {emojiscape} package.

Really?

Regular readers will know that this blog is where I implement whimsical R daydreams. Today is no exception: Iâ€™ve made a tiny package to print a little randomised emoji scene to my console.

Why? Iâ€™ve seen people make cute emoji-based bots, which Iâ€™ve been interested in after making the @londonmapbot Twitter bot (post, source, BotWiki). I also enjoyed the fun of mild randomisation in my last post about #RecreationThursday.

Iâ€™ve made this completely for my own amusement, so no guarantees whatsoever.

Play god

Install

You can install {emojiscape} from GitHub.

## remotes::install_github("matt-dray/emojiscape")
library(emojiscape)

The package has one dependency: the GitHub-hosted {emo} package1 by Hadley Wickham. It implements emoji in R like emo::ji("sauropod") ğŸ¦•.

Thereâ€™s no guarantee that these particular emoji will display correctly on your device and they may have different designs if youâ€™re using another operating system.

Generate

Letâ€™s generate() a scene.

The first one is nuts, lol: a classic deciduous woods.2

Hold your breath, weâ€™re going to space. You can resize the output, but space is basically infinite and my console is not.

generate(
  terrain = "space",
  grid_size = 7  # i.e. a 7x7 grid
)

Here endeth the puns.

Terrains

So what are all the available terrain options?

paste(as.list(args(generate))$terrain)[-1]
 [1] "arable"      "city"        "desert"      "forest"      "garden"     
 [6] "liminal"     "mountains"   "ocean"       "pastoral"    "polar"      
[11] "rainforest"  "sky"         "space"       "suburbs"     "traffic"    
[16] "undergrowth" "woods"

This list may go out of date if more options are added in future.

Expand the sections below to see each terrainâ€™s emoji set and previews of the output for each one.

Frequencies

Use get_set() to see each terrainâ€™s emoji set and their â€˜suggested frequencyâ€™ slot. In general, the most common emoji is the one that defines the background or vegetation and the rarer ones are creatures or whatever.

get_set("mountains")
    terrain                 name emoji     freq
1 mountains             mountain     â›°   common
2 mountains snow_capped_mountain     ğŸ”ï¸ uncommon
3 mountains                 goat    ğŸ     rare

But you can totally mess with these emoji sampling probabilities in generate().

Any The Mountain Goats fans?

generate(
  terrain = "mountains",
  prob_common = 0.1,
  prob_uncommon = 0.2,
  prob_rare = 0.7  # INCREASE GOAT FREQUENCY
)
ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ 
ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ 
ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ 
ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ 
ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ 
ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ 
ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ â›° ğŸ â›° ğŸ

ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ”ï¸ â›° ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ ğŸ ğŸ”ï¸ ğŸ

Approach

The generate() function is pretty simple. What it does is:

  1. Creates a vector of emojis with a length of grid_size() squared, sampled from the specified terrain set with frequencies from the prob_* arguments
  2. Coerces this vector to a matrix of length and width grid_size() (i.e. a square)
  3. Loops over each row of the matrix with cat() to print the output to the console

It works.

Expansion

If you really want, you can add a terrain option by raising a new issue or pull request in the {emojiscape} GitHub repo. These are specified in the .get_emoji() function in the /R/utils.R script.
